sen.j: 成務天皇（せいむてんのう、景行天皇14年（84年）- 成務天皇60年6月11日 (旧暦)（190年7月30日））は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に伝えられる第13代の天皇（在位：成務天皇元年1月5日 (旧暦)（131年2月18日） - 同60年6月11日（190年7月30日））。
sen.e: Emperor Seimu (84 – July 30, 190) is the 13th emperor (reigned from February 18, 131 to July 30, 190) written in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

Emperor Seimu (84 – July 29, 190) was the 13th emperor (reigned from February 18, 131 to July 29, 190) written in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: is→was、一部ユリウス→グレゴリオ暦に修正、全角クォーテーション→半角に修正、"Kojiki""Nihonshoki"の前にthe追加
sen.e: Emperor Seimu (84 – July 29, 190) was the 13th emperor (reigned from February 18, 131 to July 29, 190) written in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 和風諡号は稚足彦尊（わかたらしひこのみこと）、若帯日子天皇（わかたらしひこのすめらのみこと、古事記）。
sen.e: His Japanese-style posthumous name is Wakatarashihiko no mikoto or Wakatarashihiko no sumera mikoto (in Kojiki).
His Japanese-style posthumous name was Wakatarashihiko no mikoto or Wakatarashihiko no sumera mikoto (in Kojiki).
His Japanese-style posthumous name was Wakatarashihiko no mikoto or Wakatarashihiko no sumera mikoto (in Kojiki).

sen.j: 「タラシヒコ」という称号は12代景行、13代成務、14代仲哀の3天皇が持ち、ずっと下がって7世紀前半に在位したことの確実な34代舒明、35代皇極の両天皇も同じ称号をもつ。
sen.e: The title 'Tarashihiko' was used for the 12th Emperor Keiko, the 13th Emperor Seimu, the 14th Emperor Chuai, and after an interval, the 34th Emperor Jomei and the 35th Emperor Kogyoku who surely existed in the early seventh century also had the same title.

The title 'Tarashihiko' was used for the 12th Emperor Keiko, the 13th Emperor Seimu, the 14th Emperor Chuai, and after an interval, the 34th Emperor Jomei and the 35th Empress Kogyoku who surely existed in the early seventh century also had the same title.
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーション→半角に修正、女性天皇のため、Emperor Kogyoku→Empress Kogyokuとしました。
sen.e: The title 'Tarashihiko' was used for the 12th Emperor Keiko, the 13th Emperor Seimu, the 14th Emperor Chuai, and after an interval, the 34th Emperor Jomei and the 35th Empress Kogyoku who surely existed in the early seventh century also had the same title.

sen.j: このことから、タラシヒコの称号は7世紀前半のものであり、12,13,14代の称号は後世の造作ということになり、成務天皇の実在性には疑問が出されている。
sen.e: That means the title of Tarashihiko originated in the early seventh century and the titles of the 12th, 13th and 14th were made in later days, and therefore, the existence of the Emperor Seimuis is being questioned.

That means the title of Tarashihiko originated in the early seventh century and the titles of the 12th, 13th and 14th were made in later days, and therefore, the existence of the Emperor Seimu is being questioned.

That means the title of Tarashihiko originated in the early seventh century and the titles of the 12th, 13th and 14th were made in later days, and therefore, the existence of the Emperor Seimu is being questioned.

sen.j: 『記・紀』に載せる成務天皇の旧辞部分の記事は、他の天皇のそれに比して極端に文量が少なく、史実性には疑いが持たれているものの、実在を仮定すれば、その年代は4世紀半ばに当たるか。
sen.e: The description of the Emperor Seimu in Kyuji (mythical tradition) of the "Kojiki and.Nihonshoki" is far less than that of the other emperors, therefore, his historical existence is being suspected, but if he did exist, it might have been in the middle of the fourth century.

The description of the Emperor Seimu in Kyuji (mythical tradition) of the "Kojiki and Nihonshoki" is far less than that of the other emperors, therefore, his historical existence is being suspected, but if he did exist, it might have been in the middle of the fourth century.

The description of the Emperor Seimu in Kyuji (mythical tradition) of the "Kojiki and Nihonshoki" is far less than that of the other emperors, therefore, his historical existence is being suspected, but if he did exist, it might have been in the middle of the fourth century.

sen.j: 皇居
sen.e: Imperial palace
Imperial palace
Imperial palace

sen.j: 都は志賀高穴穂宮（しがのたかあなほのみや、現在の滋賀県大津市穴太）。
sen.e: His palace was Shigatakaanahomiya (currently, at Anou, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).
His palace was Shiga no Takaanaho no miya (currently, at Anou, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Shigatakaanahomiya→Shiga no Takaanaho no miyaとしました。
sen.e: His palace was Shiga no Takaanaho no miya (currently, at Anou, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: 『古事記』に「若帯日子天皇、近江国の志賀の高穴穂宮に坐しまして、天の下治らしめしき」とある。
sen.e: "Kojiki" says 'Wakatarashihiko no sumera mikoto ruled the world residing at the palace of Takaanaho at Shiga in Omi Province.'
The "Kojiki" says 'Wakatarashihiko no sumera mikoto ruled the world residing at the palace of Takaanaho at Shiga in Omi Province.'
sen.cmt: The "Kojiki"とし、全角クォーテーション→半角に修正
sen.e: The "Kojiki" says 'Wakatarashihiko no sumera mikoto ruled the world residing at the palace of Takaanaho at Shiga in Omi Province.'

sen.j: 成務天皇を架空と見る立場からは、天智天皇の近江宮のモデルを過去に投影した創作とする。
sen.e: For those who see the Emperor Seimu as fictitious, the palace was a creation reflecting the Omi no miya Palace of the Emperor Tenji as a model.
For those who see the Emperor Seimu as fictitious, the palace was a creation reflecting the Omi no miya Palace of the Emperor Tenji as a model.
For those who see the Emperor Seimu as fictitious, the palace was a creation reflecting the Omi no miya Palace of the Emperor Tenji as a model.

sen.j: 景行天皇51年（121年）に立太子、成務天皇元年（131年）正月に即位。
sen.e: He was formally installed as Crown Prince in 121and was enthroned in January, 131.
He was formally installed as Crown Prince in 121 and was enthroned in February, 131.
sen.cmt: スペース追加、旧暦→新暦に修正
sen.e: He was formally installed as Crown Prince in 121 and was enthroned in February, 131.

sen.j: 3年（133年）に武内宿禰を大臣とした。
sen.e: He appointed TAKENOUCHI no Sukune as minister in 133.
He appointed TAKENOUCHI no Sukune as minister in 133.
He appointed TAKENOUCHI no Sukune as minister in 133.

sen.j: 5年（135年）9月、諸国に令して、行政区画として国 郡（くにこおり）・県邑（あがたむら）を定め、それぞれに国造（くにのみやつこ）・稲置（いなぎ）等を任命して、山河を隔にして国県を分かち、阡陌（南北東西の道）に随って邑里（むら）を定め、古代日本の地方官制の整備を図った。
sen.e: He issued an imperial ordinance and established Kuni Kori and Agata Mura as administrative districts, and then he appointed Kuni no miyatsuko (provincial governor) and Inagi for each district, drew boundaries at mountains and rivers between provinces, and laid down Mura (village) along Senpaku (roads) to develop local bureaucratic system in ancient Japan

In September 135, he issued an imperial ordinance and established Kuni Kori and Agata Mura as administrative districts, and then he appointed Kuni no miyatsuko (provincial governor) and Inagi (regional official responsible for rice storage) for each district, drew boundaries at mountains and rivers between provinces, and laid down Mura (village) along Senpaku (roads) to develop local bureaucratic system in ancient Japan.
sen.cmt: 「5年（135年）9月」→訳漏れのため訳出、ピリオド追加、Inagiの補足追加 (参照: http://tangorin.com/words/inagi)
sen.e: In September 135, he issued an imperial ordinance and established Kuni Kori and Agata Mura as administrative districts, and then he appointed Kuni no miyatsuko (provincial governor) and Inagi (regional official responsible for rice storage) for each district, drew boundaries at mountains and rivers between provinces, and laid down Mura (village) along Senpaku (roads) to develop local bureaucratic system in ancient Japan.

sen.j: ここにおいて、人民は安住し、天下太平であったという。
sen.e: It is said that people there lived in stability with complete peace of mind.
It is said that people there lived in stability with complete peace of mind.
It is said that people there lived in stability with complete peace of mind.

sen.j: これらは『古事記』にも大同小異で、「武内宿禰を大臣として、大国・小国の国造を定めたまひ、また国々の堺、また大県小県の県主を定めたまひき」とある。
sen.e: These descriptions are almost the same with those in "Kojiki", that goes 'making TAKENOUCHI no Sukune a minister, he appointed Kuni no miyatsuko for small and large provinces, and defined boundaries between provinces and designated Agatanushi (territorial ruler) for small and large territories'.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These descriptions are almost the same with those in the "Kojiki," that goes 'making TAKENOUCHI no Sukune a minister, he appointed Kuni no miyatsuko for small and large provinces, and defined boundaries between provinces and designated Agatanushi (territorial ruler) for small and large territories.'
sen.cmt: in “Kojiki”→in the "Kojiki"とし、カンマ・ピリオドの位置を移動
sen.e: These descriptions are almost the same with those in the "Kojiki," that goes 'making TAKENOUCHI no Sukune a minister, he appointed Kuni no miyatsuko for small and large provinces, and defined boundaries between provinces and designated Agatanushi (territorial ruler) for small and large territories.'

sen.j: 『先代旧事本紀』の「国造本紀」に載せる国造の半数がその設置時期を成務朝と伝えていることも注目される。
sen.e: It is worth noting that the half of Kuni no miyatsuko in 'Kokuzohongi' (the original record of provincial governors) of "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History) was said to have been established under the reign of the Emperor Seimu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is worth noting that the half of Kuni no miyatsuko in the 'Kokuzohongi' (the original record of provincial governors) of the "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History) was said to have been established under the reign of the Emperor Seimu.

It is worth noting that the half of Kuni no miyatsuko in the 'Kokuzohongi' (the original record of provincial governors) of the "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History) was said to have been established under the reign of the Emperor Seimu.

sen.j: 甥の足仲彦尊（仲哀天皇）を皇太子に立て、60年（190年）6月に崩御、107歳。
sen.e: He installed his nephew, Tarashinakatsuhiko no mikoto (Emperor Chuai) as Crown Prince and passed away in June, 190 at age 107.
He installed his nephew, Tarashinakatsuhiko no mikoto (Emperor Chuai) as Crown Prince and passed away in July, 190 at the age of 107.
sen.cmt: 旧暦→新暦に修正、at age 107→at the age of 107としました。
sen.e: He installed his nephew, Tarashinakatsuhiko no mikoto (Emperor Chuai) as Crown Prince and passed away in July, 190 at the age of 107.

sen.j: 『古事記』に95歳という。
sen.e: "Kojiki" says he was 95 years old then.
The "Kojiki" says he was 95 years old then.
The "Kojiki" says he was 95 years old then.

sen.j: 『延喜式』諸陵寮によれば、狭城盾列池後陵（さきのたたなみのいけしりのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: According to Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) of "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), he was buried in Sakinotatanaminoikeshirino misasagi.

According to Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) of the "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), he was buried in Sakinotatanami no ikeshiri no misasagi.
sen.cmt: the追加、Sakinotatanaminoikeshirino misasagi→Sakinotatanami no ikeshiri no misasagiとしました。
sen.e: According to Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) of the "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), he was buried in Sakinotatanami no ikeshiri no misasagi.

sen.j: 『書紀』に「狭城盾列陵」、『古事記』に「沙紀の多他那美（たたなみ）」とある。
sen.e: It is referred to as 'Sakinotatanami no misasagi' in "Nihonshoki" and 'Sakinotatanami' in "Kojiki".
It is referred to as 'Sakinotatanami no misasagi' in the "Nihonshoki" and 'Sakinotatanami' in the "Kojiki."
sen.cmt: in “Nihonshoki”→in the "Nihonshoki"、in “Kojiki”→in the "Kojiki"とし、ピリオドの位置を移動
sen.e: It is referred to as 'Sakinotatanami no misasagi' in the "Nihonshoki" and 'Sakinotatanami' in the "Kojiki."

sen.j: 現在、同陵は奈良県奈良市山陵町の佐紀石塚山古墳（前方後円墳・全長218m）に比定される。
sen.e: The mausoleum is now identified as Sakiishizukayama-kofun Tumulus (218-meter-long keyhole-shaped burial mound) in Misasagi Town, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
The mausoleum is now identified as Sakiishizukayama-kofun Tumulus (218-meter-long keyhole-shaped burial mound) in Misasagi-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
The mausoleum is now identified as Sakiishizukayama-kofun Tumulus (218-meter-long keyhole-shaped burial mound) in Misasagi-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 江戸時代までたびたび盗掘の被害に遭った古墳の一で、犯人は流罪・磔などに処されたという。
sen.e: It is said that this tumulus was robbed several times by the Edo period and the culprits were exiled or crucified.
It is said that this tumulus was robbed several times by the Edo period and the culprits were exiled or crucified.
It is said that this tumulus was robbed several times by the Edo period and the culprits were exiled or crucified.
